#Text=Liberal Democrat leadership contenders address party members
#Text=Saturday , January 14 , 2006
#Text=Four declared contenders in the Liberal Democrats leadership contest today addressed party members at the London School of Economics .
#Text=The contest was initiated after Charles Kennedy admitted in a press conference that he had previously sought professional help for an alcohol problem .
#Text=Initially , Mr Kennedy had stated that he intended to run for re-election in a leadership contest .
#Text=However , after 25 MPs said they would refuse to serve on the front bench under Charles Kennedy , he resigned immediately and said he would play no part in the leadership contest .

#Text=At the meeting today , which had been organised before Kennedy 's resignation , the four candidates - Sir Menzies Campbell , Mark Oaten , Simon Hughes and Chris Huhne - were permitted to make 12 minute speeches outlining their vision for the party .
#Text=The speeches were broadcast live and unedited on BBC News 24 , with clips from them appearing in news bulletins later that evening .

#Text=The current acting party leader , Menzies Cambell , the first to declare his intention to stand , said that he wanted new thinking to tackle poverty and social injustice , new thinking to underpin a modern constitution , and a radical democratic revolution .
#Text=He suggested that international cooperation was the way to make poverty history , and spoke against the decision to invade Iraq .
#Text=He stressed his " experience " as being a key quality needed for a Liberal Democrat leader .
#Text=The MP for the Winchester constituency , Mark Oaten , praised the success of previous leader Charles Kennedy .
#Text=He pledged to do all he could to defeat attacks on civil liberties in coming months , and stressed that it was important to try and defeat the identity card bill due to be voted on next month .
#Text=He suggested that the party " needed to be more progressive , ambitious , and optimistic " and should avoid talking about politics in terms of ' left ' or ' right ' .

#Text=Speaking about the environment , he said that the solution was not to " dictate how people should lead their lives " but offer positive measures enabling people to take their environmental responsibilities seriously .

#Text=The current party president , Simon Hughes , who unsuccessfully ran for the London mayoral position in 2004 , promised a consultative leadership and said he wanted the Liberal Democrats to be the " party of fairness " .

column1: #Text=He attacked Prime Minister Tony Blair as having ' failed ' , with the poorest paying a bigger propotion of their income in taxes than the richest .
#Text=He said that there was a need to tackle inequality , and promised to stick with the policy of taxes to tackle inequality .
#Text=He also supported greater decentralisation of power , and stressed the continued importance of environmental policies .
#Text=Former MEP Chris Huhne focused on environmental issues , questioning the government 's lack of conviction to the Kyoto targets and the panicked response to the fuel protests .

#Text=He spoke against David Cameron 's lack of environmental conviction and suggested that only realistic means of tackling carbon emissions was through taxation , which could help change behaviour .
#Text=Higher eco-taxes should be combined with lower personal taxes for those at the bottom of the economic scale , he argued .
#Text=He also promoted greater powers and accountability for local authorities .

#Text=The nominations for leadership candidates close on 25th January , with candidates needing the declared support of at least 7 MPs and 200 party members from at least 20 different constituencies .
#Text=No other candidates other than the four above are expected to stand .
#Text=The vote closes on the 1st March , with the result due to be announced on the 2nd March .
